scene.scenepersonae: (Roman Citizens, Menenius Agrippa, Martius, First Messenger, Sicinius Velutus, Junius Brutus, Cominius, Titus Lartius, Roman Senators)
scene.stagedir: Enter a company of mutinous Roman Citizens with staves, clubs, and other weapons.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

speech.speaker: ALL. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Speak, speak.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: You are all resolv’d rather to die than to famish?

speech.speaker: ALL. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Resolv’d, resolv’d.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: First, you know Caius Martius is chief enemy to the people.

speech.speaker: ALL. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: We know’t, we know’t.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Let us kill him, and we’ll have corn at our own price. Is’t a verdict?

speech.speaker: ALL. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: No more talking on’t; let it be done. Away, away!

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: One word, good citizens.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good. What authority surfeits on would relieve us. If they would yield us but the superfluity while it were wholesome, we might guess they reliev’d us humanely; but they think we are too dear. The leanness that afflicts us, the object of our misery, is as an inventory to particularize their abundance; our sufferance is a gain to them. Let us revenge this with our pikes, ere we become rakes; for the gods know I speak this in hunger for bread, not in thirst for revenge.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Would you proceed especially against Caius Martius?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Against him first; he’s a very dog to the commonalty.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Consider you what services he has done for his country?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Very well, and could be content to give him good report for’t, but that he pays himself with being proud.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Nay, but speak not maliciously.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he did it to that end. Though soft-conscienc’d men can be content to say it was for his country, he did it to please his mother, and to be partly proud, which he is, even to the altitude of his virtue.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: What he cannot help in his nature, you account a vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations; he hath faults (with surplus) to tire in repetition.
What shouts are these? The other side a’ th’ city is risen; why stay we prating here? To th’ Capitol!

speech.speaker: ALL. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Come, come.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Soft, who comes here?

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Worthy Menenius Agrippa, one that hath always lov’d the people.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: He’s one honest enough; would all the rest were so!

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: What work’s, my countrymen, in hand? Where go you
With bats and clubs? The matter? Speak, I pray you.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Our business is not unknown to th’ Senate; they have had inkling this fortnight what we intend to do, which now we’ll show ’em in deeds. They say poor suitors have strong breaths; they shall know we have strong arms too.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbors,
Will you undo yourselves?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: We cannot, sir, we are undone already.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: I tell you, friends, most charitable care
Have the patricians of you. For your wants,
Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well
Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them
Against the Roman state, whose course will on
The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs
Of more strong link asunder than can ever
Appear in your impediment. For the dearth,
The gods, not the patricians, make it, and
Your knees to them (not arms) must help. Alack,
You are transported by calamity
Thither where more attends you, and you slander
The helms o’ th’ state, who care for you like fathers,
When you curse them as enemies.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Care for us? True indeed! They ne’er car’d for us yet. Suffer us to famish, and their store-houses cramm’d with grain; make edicts for usury, to support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act establish’d against the rich, and provide more piercing statutes daily to chain up and restrain the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will; and there’s all the love they bear us.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Either you must
Confess yourselves wondrous malicious,
Or be accus’d of folly. I shall tell you
A pretty tale. It may be you have heard it,
But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture
To stale ’t a little more.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Well, I’ll hear it, sir; yet you must not think to fob off our disgrace with a tale. But and’t please you, deliver.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: There was a time when all the body’s members
Rebell’d against the belly; thus accus’d it:
That only like a gulf it did remain
I’ th’ midst a’ th’ body, idle and unactive,
Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing
Like labor with the rest, where th’ other instruments
Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel,
And, mutually participate, did minister
Unto the appetite and affection common
Of the whole body. The belly answer’d—

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Well, sir, what answer made the belly?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Sir, I shall tell you. With a kind of smile,
Which ne’er came from the lungs, but even thus—
For, look you, I may make the belly smile
As well as speak—it tauntingly replied
To th’ discontented members, the mutinous parts
That envied his receipt; even so most fitly
As you malign our senators for that
They are not such as you.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Your belly’s answer—what?
The kingly-crowned head, the vigilant eye,
The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier,
Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter,
With other muniments and petty helps
In this our fabric, if that they—

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: What then?
’Fore me, this fellow speaks! What then? What then?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Should by the cormorant belly be restrain’d,
Who is the sink a’ th’ body—

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Well, what then?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: The former agents, if they did complain,
What could the belly answer?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: I will tell you;
If You’ll bestow a small (of what you have little)
Patience awhile, you’st hear the belly’s answer.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Y’ are long about it.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Note me this, good friend:
Your most grave belly was deliberate,
Not rash like his accusers, and thus answered:
“True is it, my incorporate friends,” quoth he,
“That I receive the general food at first
Which you do live upon; and fit it is,
Because I am the store-house and the shop
Of the whole body. But, if you do remember,
I send it through the rivers of your blood,
Even to the court, the heart, to th’ seat o’ th’ brain,
And, through the cranks and offices of man,
The strongest nerves and small inferior veins
From me receive that natural competency
Whereby they live. And though that all at once”—
You, my good friends, this says the belly, mark me.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Ay, sir, well, well.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: “Though all at once cannot
See what I do deliver out to each,
Yet I can make my audit up, that all
From me do back receive the flour of all,
And leave me but the bran.” What say you to’t?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: It was an answer. How apply you this?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: The senators of Rome are this good belly,
And you the mutinous members: for examine
Their counsels and their cares; digest things rightly
Touching the weal a’ th’ common, you shall find
No public benefit which you receive
But it proceeds or comes from them to you,
And no way from yourselves. What do you think,
You, the great toe of this assembly?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: I the great toe? Why the great toe?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: For that, being one o’ th’ lowest, basest, poorest
Of this most wise rebellion, thou goest foremost;
Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run,
Lead’st first to win some vantage.
But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs,
Rome and her rats are at the point of battle,
The one side must have bale.
Hail, noble Martius!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Thanks. What’s the matter, you dissentious rogues,
That rubbing the poor itch of your opinion
Make yourselves scabs?

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: We have ever your good word.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: He that will give good words to thee will flatter
Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs,
That like nor peace nor war? The one affrights you,
The other makes you proud. He that trusts to you,
Where he should find you lions, finds you hares;
Where foxes, geese. You are no surer, no,
Than is the coal of fire upon the ice,
Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is
To make him worthy whose offense subdues him,
And curse that justice did it. Who deserves greatness
Deserves your hate; and your affections are
A sick man’s appetite, who desires most that
Which would increase his evil. He that depends
Upon your favors swims with fins of lead,
And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust ye?
With every minute you do change a mind,
And call him noble, that was now your hate;
Him vild, that was your garland. What’s the matter,
That in these several places of the city
You cry against the noble Senate, who
(Under the gods) keep you in awe, which else
Would feed on one another? What’s their seeking?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: For corn at their own rates, whereof they say
The city is well stor’d.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Hang ’em! They say?
They’ll sit by th’ fire, and presume to know
What’s done i’ th’ Capitol; who’s like to rise,
Who thrives, and who declines; side factions, and give out
Conjectural marriages, making parties strong,
And feebling such as stand not in their liking
Below their cobbled shoes. They say there’s grain enough?
Would the nobility lay aside their ruth
And let me use my sword, I’d make a quarry
With thousands of these quarter’d slaves, as high
As I could pick my lance.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded;
For though abundantly they lack discretion,
Yet are they passing cowardly. But I beseech you,
What says the other troop?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: They are dissolv’d. Hang ’em!
They said they were an-hungry; sigh’d forth proverbs—
That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat,
That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not
Corn for the rich men only. With these shreds
They vented their complainings, which being answer’d,
And a petition granted them—a strange one,
To break the heart of generosity
And make bold power look pale—they threw their caps
As they would hang them on the horns a’ th’ moon,
Shouting their emulation.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: What is granted them?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms,
Of their own choice. One’s Junius Brutus,
Sicinius Velutus, and I know not—’sdeath,
The rabble should have first unroof’d the city
Ere so prevail’d with me; it will in time
Win upon power, and throw forth greater themes
For insurrection’s arguing.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: This is strange.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Go get you home, you fragments!

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: Where’s Caius Martius?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Here. What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I am glad on’t, then we shall ha’ means to vent
Our musty superfluity. See, our best elders.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sicinius Velutus, Junius Brutus, Cominius, Titus Lartius, with other Senators.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SEN.
speech.line: Martius, ’tis true that you have lately told us,
The Volsces are in arms.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: They have a leader,
Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to’t.
I sin in envying his nobility;
And were I any thing but what I am,
I would wish me only he.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: You have fought together?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Were half to half the world by th’ ears, and he
Upon my party, I’d revolt, to make
Only my wars with him. He is a lion
That I am proud to hunt.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SEN.
speech.line: Then, worthy Martius,
Attend upon Cominius to these wars.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: It is your former promise.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Sir, it is,
And I am constant. Titus Lartius, thou
Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus’ face.
What, art thou stiff? Stand’st out?

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: No, Caius Martius,
I’ll lean upon one crutch, and fight with t’ other,
Ere stay behind this business.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: O, true-bred!

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SEN.
speech.line: Your company to th’ Capitol, where I know
Our greatest friends attend us.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: Lead you on.
Follow Cominius; we must follow you,
Right worthy you priority.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Noble Martius!

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SEN.
speech.line: Hence to your homes, be gone!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Nay, let them follow.
The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither
To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutiners,
Your valor puts well forth; pray follow.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt. Roman Citizens steal away. Manent Sicinius and Brutus.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Was ever man so proud as is this Martius?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: He has no equal.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: When we were chosen tribunes for the people—

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Mark’d you his lip and eyes?

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Nay, but his taunts.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Being mov’d, he will not spare to gird the gods.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Bemock the modest moon.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: The present wars devour him! He is grown
Too proud to be so valiant.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Such a nature,
Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow
Which he treads on at noon. But I do wonder
His insolence can brook to be commanded
Under Cominius.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Fame, at the which he aims,
In whom already he’s well grac’d, cannot
Better be held nor more attain’d than by
A place below the first; for what miscarries
Shall be the general’s fault, though he perform
To th’ utmost of a man, and giddy censure
Will then cry out of Martius, “O, if he
Had borne the business!”

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Besides, if things go well,
Opinion that so sticks on Martius shall
Of his demerits rob Cominius.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Come.
Half all Cominius’ honors are to Martius,
Though Martius earn’d them not; and all his faults
To Martius shall be honors, though indeed
In aught he merit not.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Let’s hence, and hear
How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion,
More than his singularity, he goes
Upon this present action.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Let’s along.

scene.stagedir: Enter Tullus Aufidius with Senators of Corioli.

speech.speaker: 1. VOL. SEN.
speech.line: So, your opinion is, Aufidius,
That they of Rome are ent’red in our counsels,
And know how we proceed.

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: Is it not yours?
What ever have been thought on in this state
That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome
Had circumvention? ’Tis not four days gone
Since I heard thence; these are the words—I think
I have the letter here; yes, here it is:

line.recite: “They have press’d a power, but it is not known
Whether for east or west. The dearth is great,
The people mutinous; and it is rumor’d,
(Who is of Rome worse hated than of you),
And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman,
These three lead on this preparation
Whither ’tis bent. Most likely ’tis for you;

speech.speaker: 1. VOL. SEN.
speech.line: Our army’s in the field.
We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready
To answer us.

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: Nor did you think it folly
To keep your great pretences veil’d till when
They needs must show themselves, which in the hatching,
It seem’d, appear’d to Rome. By the discovery
We shall be shorten’d in our aim, which was
To take in many towns ere (almost) Rome
Should know we were afoot.

speech.speaker: 2. VOL. SEN.
speech.line: Noble Aufidius,
Take your commission, hie you to your bands,
Let us alone to guard Corioles.
If they set down before ’s, for the remove
Bring up your army; but, I think, You’ll find
Th’ have not prepar’d for us.

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: O, doubt not that,
I speak from certainties. Nay more,
Some parcels of their power are forth already,
And only hitherward. I leave your honors.
If we and Caius Martius chance to meet,
’Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike
Till one can do no more.

speech.speaker: ALL. VOL. SEN.
speech.line: The gods assist you!

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: And keep your honors safe!

speech.speaker: 1. VOL. SEN.
speech.line: Farewell.

speech.speaker: 2. VOL. SEN.
speech.line: Farewell.

speech.speaker: ALL. VOL. SEN.
speech.line: Farewell.

scene.scenelocation: Rome. A room in Coriolanus’ house.
scene.stagedir: Enter Volumnia and Virgilia, mother and wife to Martius; they set them down on two low stools and sew.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: I pray you, daughter, sing, or express yourself in a more comfortable sort. If my son were my husband, I should freelier rejoice in that absence wherein he won honor than in the embracements of his bed where he would show most love. When yet he was but tender-bodied and the only son of my womb; when youth with comeliness pluck’d all gaze his way; when for a day of kings’ entreaties a mother should not sell him an hour from her beholding; I, considering how honor would become such a person, that it was no better than picture-like to hang by th’ wall, if renown made it not stir, was pleas’d to let him seek danger where he was like to find fame. To a cruel war I sent him, from whence he return’d, his brows bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang not more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child than now in first seeing he had prov’d himself a man.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: But had he died in the business, madam, how then?

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Then his good report should have been my son; I therein would have found issue. Hear me profess sincerely; had I a dozen sons, each in my love alike, and none less dear than thine and my good Martius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for their country than one voluptuously surfeit out of action.

speech.speaker: GENT.
speech.line: Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: Beseech you give me leave to retire myself.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Indeed you shall not.
Methinks I hear hither your husband’s drum;
See him pluck Aufidius down by th’ hair;
As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him.
Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus:
“Come on, you cowards, you were got in fear,
Though you were born in Rome!” His bloody brow
With his mail’d hand then wiping, forth he goes,
Like to a harvest-man that’s task’d to mow
Or all or lose his hire.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: His bloody brow? O Jupiter, no blood!

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Away, you fool! It more becomes a man
Than gilt his trophy. The breasts of Hecuba,
When she did suckle Hector, look’d not lovelier
Than Hector’s forehead when it spit forth blood
At Grecian sword, contemning. Tell Valeria
We are fit to bid her welcome.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: He’ll beat Aufidius’ head below his knee,
And tread upon his neck.

scene.stagedir: Enter Valeria with an Usher and a Gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: My ladies both, good day to you.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Sweet madam.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: I am glad to see your ladyship.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: How do you both? You are manifest house-keepers. What are you sewing here? A fine spot, in good faith. How does your little son?

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: I thank your ladyship; well, good madam.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: He had rather see the swords and hear a drum than look upon his schoolmaster.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: A’ my word, the father’s son. I’ll swear ’tis a very pretty boy. A’ my troth, I look’d upon him a’ We’n’sday half an hour together; h’as such a confirm’d countenance. I saw him run after a gilded butterfly, and when he caught it, he let it go again, and after it again, and over and over he comes, and up again; catch’d it again: or whether his fallen rag’d him, or how ’twas, he did so set his teeth and tear it. O, I warrant, how he mammock’d it!

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: One on ’s father’s moods.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Indeed la, ’tis a noble child.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: A crack, madam.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Come, lay aside your stitchery, I must have you play the idle huswife with me this afternoon.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: No, good madam, I will not out of doors.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Not out of doors?

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: She shall, she shall.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: Indeed no, by your patience; I’ll not over the threshold till my lord return from the wars.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably. Come, you must go visit the good lady that lies in.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with my prayers; but I cannot go thither.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Why, I pray you?

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: ’Tis not to save labor, nor that I want love.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: You would be another Penelope: yet they say, all the yarn she spun in Ulysses’ absence did but fill Ithaca full of moths. Come, I would your cambric were sensible as your finger, that you might leave pricking it for pity. Come, you shall go with us.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: No, good madam, pardon me, indeed I will not forth.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: In truth la, go with me, and I’ll tell you excellent news of your husband.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: O, good madam, there can be none yet.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from him last night.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: Indeed, madam?

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: In earnest, it’s true; I heard a senator speak it. Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth; against whom Cominius the general is gone, with one part of our Roman power. Your lord and Titus Lartius are set down before their city Corioles; they nothing doubt prevailing, and to make it brief wars. This is true, on mine honor, and so I pray go with us.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: Give me excuse, good madam, I will obey you in every thing hereafter.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Let her alone, lady; as she is now, she will but disease our better mirth.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: In troth, I think she would. Fare you well then. Come, good sweet lady. Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy solemnness out a’ door, and go along with us.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: No, at a word, madam; indeed I must not.
I wish you much mirth.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: Well, then farewell.

scene.scenepersonae: (Martius, Titus Lartius, Captains, Roman Soldiers, Second Messenger, Volscian Senators, Army of the Volsces)
scene.stagedir: Enter Martius, Titus Lartius, with Drum and Colors, with Captains and Roman Soldiers, as before the city Corioli; to them a Messenger.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Yonder comes news: a wager they have met.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: My horse to yours, no.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: ’Tis done.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: Agreed.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Say, has our general met the enemy?

speech.speaker: 2. MESS.
speech.line: They lie in view, but have not spoke as yet.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: So, the good horse is mine.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I’ll buy him of you.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: No, I’ll nor sell nor give him; lend you him I will
For half a hundred years. Summon the town.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: How far off lie these armies?

speech.speaker: 2. MESS.
speech.line: Within this mile and half.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Then shall we hear their ’larum, and they ours.
Now, Mars, I prithee make us quick in work,
That we with smoking swords may march from hence
To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast.
speech.stagedir: They sound a parley. Enter two Senators with others on the walls of Corioli.
speech.line: Tullus Aufidius, is he within your walls?

speech.speaker: 1. VOL. SEN.
speech.line: No, nor a man that fears you less than he,
That’s lesser than a little.
Hark, our drums
Are bringing forth our youth. We’ll break our walls
Rather than they shall pound us up; our gates,
Which yet seem shut, we have but pinn’d with rushes,
They’ll open of themselves.
Hark you, far off!
There is Aufidius. List what work he makes
Amongst your cloven army.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: O, they are at it!

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: Their noise be our instruction. Ladders ho!

scene.stagedir: Enter the Army of the Volsces.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: They fear us not, but issue forth their city.
Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight
With hearts more proof than shields. Advance, brave Titus!
They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts,
Which makes me sweat with wrath. Come on, my fellows!
He that retires, I’ll take him for a Volsce,
And he shall feel mine edge.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. The Romans are beat back to their trenches.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: All the contagion of the south light on you,
You shames of Rome! You herd of—Biles and plagues
Plaster you o’er, that you may be abhorr’d
Farther than seen, and one infect another
Against the wind a mile! You souls of geese,
That bear the shapes of men, how have you run
From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell!
All hurt behind! Backs red, and faces pale
With flight and agued fear! Mend and charge home,
Or, by the fires of heaven, I’ll leave the foe
And make my wars on you. Look to’t; come on!
If You’ll stand fast, we’ll beat them to their wives,
As they us to our trenches. Follow ’s.
speech.stagedir: Another alarum. The Volsces fly, and Martius follows them to the gates.
speech.line: So, now the gates are ope; now prove good seconds:
’Tis for the followers fortune widens them,
Not for the fliers. Mark me, and do the like.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SOLD.
speech.line: Foolhardiness, not I.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. SOLD.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SOLD.
speech.line: See, they have shut him in.

speech.speaker: ALL. ROM. SOLD.
speech.line: To th’ pot, I warrant him.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: What is become of Martius?

speech.speaker: ALL. ROM. SOLD.
speech.line: Slain, sir, doubtless.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SOLD.
speech.line: Following the fliers at the very heels,
With them he enters; who upon the sudden
Clapp’d to their gates. He is himself alone,
To answer all the city.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: O noble fellow!
Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword,
And when it bows, stand’st up. Thou art left, Martius—
A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art,
Were not so rich a jewel. Thou wast a soldier
Even to Cato’s wish, not fierce and terrible
Only in strokes, but, with thy grim looks and
The thunder-like percussion of thy sounds,
Thou mad’st thine enemies shake, as if the world
Were feverous and did tremble.

scene.stagedir: Enter Martius bleeding, assaulted by the enemy.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SOLD.
speech.line: Look, sir.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: O, ’tis Martius!
Let’s fetch him off, or make remain alike.

scene.stagedir: They fight, and all enter the city.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM.
speech.line: This will I carry to Rome.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM.
speech.line: And I this.

speech.speaker: 3. ROM.
speech.line: A murrain on’t! I took this for silver.

scene.stagedir: Exeunt. Alarum continues still afar off.
Enter Martius and Titus Lartius with a Trumpet.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: See here these movers that do prize their hours
At a crack’d drachme! Cushions, leaden spoons,
Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would
Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves,
Ere yet the fight be done, pack up. Down with them!
And hark, what noise the general makes! To him!
There is the man of my soul’s hate, Aufidius,
Piercing our Romans; then, valiant Titus, take
Convenient numbers to make good the city,
Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste
To help Cominius.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: Worthy sir, thou bleed’st,
Thy exercise hath been too violent for
A second course of fight.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Sir, praise me not;
My work hath yet not warm’d me. Fare you well.
The blood I drop is rather physical
Than dangerous to me. To Aufidius thus
I will appear, and fight.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: Now the fair goddess Fortune
Fall deep in love with thee, and her great charms
Misguide thy opposers’ swords! Bold gentleman!
Prosperity be thy page.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Thy friend no less
Than those she placeth highest! So farewell.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: Thou worthiest Martius!
Go sound thy trumpet in the market-place;
Call thither all the officers a’ th’ town,
Where they shall know our mind. Away!

scene.stagedir: Enter Cominius, as it were in retire, with Soldiers.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Breathe you, my friends. Well fought; we are come off
Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands
Nor cowardly in retire. Believe me, sirs,
We shall be charg’d again. Whiles we have struck,
By interims and conveying gusts we have heard
The charges of our friends. The Roman gods,
Lead their successes as we wish our own,
That both our powers, with smiling fronts encount’ring,
May give you thankful sacrifice.
Thy news?

speech.speaker: 2. MESS.
speech.line: The citizens of Corioles have issued,
And given to Lartius and to Martius battle.
I saw our party to their trenches driven,
And then I came away.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Though thou speakest truth,
Methinks thou speak’st not well. How long is’t since?

speech.speaker: 2. MESS.
speech.line: Above an hour, my lord.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: ’Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums.
How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour,
And bring thy news so late?

speech.speaker: 2. MESS.
speech.line: Spies of the Volsces
Held me in chase, that I was forc’d to wheel
Three or four miles about, else had I, sir,
Half an hour since brought my report.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Who’s yonder,
That does appear as he were flea’d? O gods,
He has the stamp of Martius, and I have
Before-time seen him thus.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Come I too late?

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabor
More than I know the sound of Martius’ tongue
From every meaner man.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Come I too late?

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Ay, if you come not in the blood of others,
But mantled in your own.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: O! Let me clip ye
In arms as sound as when I woo’d, in heart
As merry as when our nuptial day was done
And tapers burnt to bedward!

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Flower of warriors,
How is’t with Titus Lartius?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: As with a man busied about decrees:
Condemning some to death, and some to exile;
Ransoming him, or pitying, threat’ning th’ other;
Holding Corioles in the name of Rome,
Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash,
To let him slip at will.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Where is that slave
Which told me they had beat you to your trenches?
Where is he? Call him hither.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Let him alone,
He did inform the truth. But for our gentlemen,
The common file (a plague—tribunes for them!),
The mouse ne’er shunn’d the cat as they did budge
From rascals worse than they.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: But how prevail’d you?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Will the time serve to tell? I do not think.
Where is the enemy? Are you lords a’ th’ field?
If not, why cease you till you are so?

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Martius,
We have at disadvantage fought, and did
Retire to win our purpose.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: How lies their battle? Know you on which side
They have plac’d their men of trust?

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: As I guess, Martius,
Their bands i’ th’ vaward are the Antiates,
Of their best trust; o’er them Aufidius,
Their very heart of hope.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I do beseech you,
By all the battles wherein we have fought,
By th’ blood we have shed together, by th’ vows
We have made to endure friends, that you directly
Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates,
And that you not delay the present, but,
Filling the air with swords advanc’d and darts,
We prove this very hour.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Though I could wish
You were conducted to a gentle bath
And balms applied to you, yet dare I never
Deny your asking. Take your choice of those
That best can aid your action.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Those are they
That most are willing. If any such be here
(As it were sin to doubt) that love this painting
Wherein you see me smear’d; if any fear
Lesser his person than an ill report;
If any think brave death outweighs bad life,
And that his country’s dearer than himself;
Let him alone, or so many so minded,
Wave thus to express his disposition,
And follow Martius.
speech.stagedir: They all shout and wave their swords, take him up in their arms, and cast up their caps.
speech.line: O, me alone! Make you a sword of me?
If these shows be not outward, which of you
But is four Volsces? None of you but is
Able to bear against the great Aufidius
A shield as hard as his. A certain number
(Though thanks to all) must I select from all; the rest
Shall bear the business in some other fight
(As cause will be obey’d). Please you to march,
And four shall quickly draw out my command,
Which men are best inclin’d.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: March on, my fellows!
Make good this ostentation, and you shall
Divide in all with us.

scene.scenepersonae: (Titus Lartius, Cominius, Caius Martius, Lieutenant to Lartius, Soldiers, Scout)
scene.stagedir: Titus Lartius, having set a guard upon Corioli, going with Drum and Trumpet toward Cominius and Caius Martius, enters with a Lieutenant, other Soldiers, and a Scout.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: So, let the ports be guarded; keep your duties,
As I have set them down. If I do send, dispatch
Those centuries to our aid; the rest will serve
For a short holding. If we lose the field,
We cannot keep the town.

speech.speaker: LIEU. LART.
speech.line: Fear not our care, sir.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: Hence; and shut your gates upon ’s.
Our guider, come, to th’ Roman camp conduct us.

scene.stagedir: Alarum as in battle. Enter Martius and Aufidius at several doors.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I’ll fight with none but thee, for I do hate thee
Worse than a promise-breaker.

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: We hate alike:
Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor
More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Let the first budger die the other’s slave,
And the gods doom him after!

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: If I fly, Martius,
Hollow me like a hare.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Within these three hours, Tullus,
Alone I fought in your Corioles walls,
And made what work I pleas’d. ’Tis not my blood
Wherein thou seest me mask’d; for thy revenge
Wrench up thy power to th’ highest.

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: Wert thou the Hector
That was the whip of your bragg’d progeny
Thou shouldst not scape me here.
speech.stagedir: Here they fight, and certain Volscian Soldiers come in the aid of Aufidius. Martius fights till they be driven in breathless.
speech.line: Officious, and not valiant, you have sham’d me
In your condemned seconds.

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Alarum. A retreat is sounded. Enter, at one door, Cominius, with the Roman Soldiers; at another door, Martius with his arm in a scarf.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: If I should tell thee o’er this thy day’s work,
Thou’t not believe thy deeds: but I’ll report it
Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles;
Where great patricians shall attend and shrug,
I’ th’ end admire; where ladies shall be frighted,
And gladly quak’d, hear more; where the dull tribunes,
That with the fusty plebeians hate thine honors,
Shall say against their hearts, “We thank the gods
Our Rome hath such a soldier.”
Yet cam’st thou to a morsel of this feast,
Having fully din’d before.

scene.stagedir: Enter Titus Lartius with his power, from the pursuit.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: O general!
Here is the steed, we the caparison.
Hadst thou beheld—

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Pray now, no more. My mother,
Who has a charter to extol her blood,
When she does praise me grieves me. I have done
As you have done—that’s what I can; induc’d
As you have been—that’s for my country:
He that has but effected his good will
Hath overta’en mine act.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: You shall not be
The grave of your deserving; Rome must know
The value of her own. ’Twere a concealment
Worse than a theft, no less than a traducement,
To hide your doings, and to silence that
Which, to the spire and top of praises vouch’d,
Would seem but modest; therefore I beseech you,
In sign of what you are, not to reward
What you have done, before our army hear me.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I have some wounds upon me, and they smart
To hear themselves rememb’red.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Should they not,
Well might they fester ’gainst ingratitude,
And tent themselves with death. Of all the horses—
Whereof we have ta’en good and good store—of all
The treasure in this field achiev’d and city,
We render you the tenth, to be ta’en forth,
Before the common distribution, at
Your only choice.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I thank you, general;
But cannot make my heart consent to take
A bribe to pay my sword. I do refuse it,
And stand upon my common part with those
That have beheld the doing.
speech.stagedir: A long flourish. They all cry, “Martius! Martius!”, cast up their caps and lances. Cominius and Lartius stand bare.
speech.line: May these same instruments, which you profane,
Never sound more! When drums and trumpets shall
I’ th’ field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be
Made all of false-fac’d soothing!
When steel grows soft as the parasite’s silk,
Let him be made an overture for th’ wars!
No more, I say! For that I have not wash’d
My nose that bled, or foil’d some debile wretch—
Which, without note, here’s many else have done—
You shout me forth
In acclamations hyperbolical,
As if I lov’d my little should be dieted
In praises sauc’d with lies.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Too modest are you;
More cruel to your good report than grateful
To us that give you truly. By your patience,
If ’gainst yourself you be incens’d, we’ll put you
(Like one that means his proper harm) in manacles,
Then reason safely with you. Therefore be it known,
As to us, to all the world, that Caius Martius
Wears this war’s garland; in token of the which,
My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him,
With all his trim belonging; and from this time,
For what he did before Corioles, call him,
With all th’ applause and clamor of the host,
Martius Caius Coriolanus! Bear
Th’ addition nobly ever!

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Martius Caius Coriolanus!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: I will go wash;
And when my face is fair, you shall perceive
Whether I blush or no; howbeit, I thank you.
I mean to stride your steed, and at all times
To undercrest your good addition
To th’ fairness of my power.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: So, to our tent;
Where, ere we do repose us, we will write
To Rome of our success. You, Titus Lartius,
Must to Corioles back. Send us to Rome
The best, with whom we may articulate
For their own good and ours.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: I shall, my lord.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: The gods begin to mock me. I, that now
Refus’d most princely gifts, am bound to beg
Of my lord general.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Take’t, ’tis yours. What is’t?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: I sometime lay here in Corioles
At a poor man’s house; he us’d me kindly.
He cried to me; I saw him prisoner;
But then Aufidius was within my view,
And wrath o’erwhelm’d my pity. I request you
To give my poor host freedom.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: O, well begg’d!
Were he the butcher of my son, he should
Be free as is the wind. Deliver him, Titus.

speech.speaker: LART.
speech.line: Martius, his name?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: By Jupiter, forgot!
I am weary, yea, my memory is tir’d.
Have we no wine here?

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Go we to our tent.
The blood upon your visage dries, ’tis time
It should be look’d to. Come.

scene.stagedir: A flourish. Cornets. Enter Tullus Aufidius bloody, with two or three Volscian Soldiers.

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: The town is ta’en!

speech.speaker: VOL. SOLD.
speech.line: ’Twill be deliver’d back on good condition.

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: Condition?
I would I were a Roman, for I cannot,
Being a Volsce, be that I am. Condition?
What good condition can a treaty find
I’ th’ part that is at mercy? Five times, Martius,
I have fought with thee; so often hast thou beat me;
And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter
As often as we eat. By th’ elements,
If e’er again I meet him beard to beard,
He’s mine, or I am his. Mine emulation
Hath not that honor in’t it had; for where
I thought to crush him in an equal force,
True sword to sword, I’ll potch at him some way,
Or wrath or craft may get him.

speech.speaker: VOL. SOLD.
speech.line: He’s the devil.

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: Bolder, though not so subtle. My valor’s poison’d
With only suff’ring stain by him; for him
Shall fly out of itself. Nor sleep nor sanctuary,
Being naked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol,
The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice,
Embarquements all of fury, shall lift up
Their rotten privilege and custom ’gainst
My hate to Martius. Where I find him, were it
At home, upon my brother’s guard, even there,
Against the hospitable canon, would I
Wash my fierce hand in ’s heart. Go you to th’ city,
Learn how ’tis held, and what they are that must
Be hostages for Rome.

speech.speaker: VOL. SOLD.
speech.line: Will not you go?

speech.speaker: AUF.
speech.line: I am attended at the cypress grove. I pray you
(’Tis south the city mills) bring me word thither
How the world goes, that to the pace of it
I may spur on my journey.

speech.speaker: VOL. SOLD.
speech.line: I shall, sir.

scene.scenepersonae: (Menenius, Sicinius, Brutus, Volumnia, Virgilia, Valeria, Cominius, Titus Lartius, Coriolanus, Captains, Soldiers, Roman Herald, Messenger)
scene.stagedir: Enter Menenius with the two tribunes of the people, Sicinius and Brutus.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: The augurer tells me we shall have news tonight.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Good or bad?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Not according to the prayer of the people, for they love not Martius.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Pray you, who does the wolf love?

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: The lamb.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Ay, to devour him, as the hungry plebeians would the noble Martius.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: He’s a lamb indeed, that baes like a bear.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: He’s a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. You two are old men: tell me one thing that I shall ask you.

speech.speaker: BOTH. MEN. AND BRU.
speech.line: Well, sir.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: In what enormity is Martius poor in, that you two have not in abundance?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: He’s poor in no one fault, but stor’d with all.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Especially in pride.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: And topping all others in boasting.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: This is strange now. Do you two know how you are censur’d here in the city, I mean of us a’ th’ right-hand file? Do you?

speech.speaker: BOTH. MEN. AND BRU.
speech.line: Why? How are we censur’d?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Because you talk of pride now—will you not be angry?

speech.speaker: BOTH. MEN. AND BRU.
speech.line: Well, well, sir, well.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Why, ’tis no great matter; for a very little thief of occasion will rob you of a great deal of patience. Give your dispositions the reins and be angry at your pleasures; at the least, if you take it as a pleasure to you in being so. You blame Martius for being proud?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: We do it not alone, sir.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: I know you can do very little alone, for your helps are many, or else your actions would grow wondrous single; your abilities are too infant-like for doing much alone. You talk of pride: O that you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your necks and make but an interior survey of your good selves! O that you could!

speech.speaker: BOTH. MEN. AND BRU.
speech.line: What then, sir?

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Why then you should discover a brace of unmeriting, proud, violent, testy magistrates (alias fools) as any in Rome.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Menenius, you are known well enough too.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of allaying Tiber in’t; said to be something imperfect in favoring the first complaint, hasty and tinder-like upon too trivial motion; one that converses more with the buttock of the night than with the forehead of the morning. What I think, I utter, and spend my malice in my breath. Meeting two such wealsmen as you are (I cannot call you Lycurguses), if the drink you give me touch my palate adversely, I make a crooked face at it. I cannot say your worships have deliver’d the matter well, when I find the ass in compound with the major part of your syllables; and though I must be content to bear with those that say you are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that tell you have good faces. If you see this in the map of my microcosm, follows it that I am known well enough too? What harm can your beesom conspectuities glean out of this character, if I be known well enough too?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: You know neither me, yourselves, nor any thing. You are ambitious for poor knaves’ caps and legs. You wear out a good wholesome forenoon in hearing a cause between an orange-wife and a forset-seller, and then rejourn the controversy of threepence to a second day of audience. When you are hearing a matter between party and party, if you chance to be pinch’d with the colic, you make faces like mummers, set up the bloody flag against all patience, and in roaring for a chamber-pot, dismiss the controversy bleeding, the more entangled by your hearing. All the peace you make in their cause is calling both the parties knaves. You are a pair of strange ones.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Come, come, you are well understood to be a perfecter giber for the table than a necessary bencher in the Capitol.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Our very priests must become mockers if they shall encounter such ridiculous subjects as you are. When you speak best unto the purpose, it is not worth the wagging of your beards, and your beards deserve not so honorable a grave as to stuff a botcher’s cushion, or to be entomb’d in an ass’s pack-saddle. Yet you must be saying Martius is proud; who, in a cheap estimation, is worth all your predecessors since Deucalion, though peradventure some of the best of ’em were hereditary hangmen. God-den to your worships; more of your conversation would infect my brain, being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians. I will be bold to take my leave of you.
How now, my as fair as noble ladies—and the moon, were she earthly, no nobler—whither do you follow your eyes so fast?

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Honorable Menenius, my boy Martius approaches. For the love of Juno, let’s go.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Ha? Martius coming home?

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Ay, worthy Menenius, and with most prosperous approbation.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Take my cap, Jupiter,
and I thank thee. Hoo! Martius coming home?

speech.speaker: BOTH VIR. AND VAL.
speech.line: Nay, ’tis true.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Look, here’s a letter from him; the state hath another, his wife another, and, I think, there’s one at home for you.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: I will make my very house reel tonight. A letter for me?

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: Yes certain, there’s a letter for you, I saw’t.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: A letter for me! It gives me an estate of seven years’ health, in which time I will make a lip at the physician. The most sovereign prescription in Galen is but empiricutic, and, to this preservative, of no better report than a horse-drench. Is he not wounded? He was wont to come home wounded.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: O no, no, no.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: O, he is wounded, I thank the gods for’t.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: So do I too, if it be not too much. Brings ’a victory in his pocket? The wounds become him.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: On ’s brows. Menenius, he comes the third time home with the oaken garland.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Has he disciplin’d Aufidius soundly?

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Titus Lartius writes they fought together, but Aufidius got off.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: And ’twas time for him too, I’ll warrant him that; and he had stay’d by him, I would not have been so fidius’d for all the chests in Corioles, and the gold that’s in them. Is the Senate possess’d of this?

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Good ladies, let’s go.—Yes, yes, yes; the Senate has letters from the general, wherein he gives my son the whole name of the war. He hath in this action outdone his former deeds doubly.

speech.speaker: VAL.
speech.line: In troth, there’s wondrous things spoke of him.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Wondrous! Ay, I warrant you, and not without his true purchasing.

speech.speaker: VIR.
speech.line: The gods grant them true!

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: True? Pow, waw.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: True? I’ll be sworn they are true. Where is he wounded?
God save your good worships! Martius is coming home; he has more cause to be proud.—Where is he wounded?

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: I’ th’ shoulder and i’ th’ left arm. There will be large cicatrices to show the people, when he shall stand for his place. He receiv’d in the repulse of Tarquin seven hurts i’ th’ body.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: One i’ th’ neck, and two i’ th’ thigh—there’s nine that I know.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: He had, before this last expedition, twenty-five wounds upon him.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Now it’s twenty-seven; every gash was an enemy’s grave.
Hark, the trumpets.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: These are the ushers of Martius: before him he carries noise, and behind him he leaves tears:
Death, that dark spirit, in ’s nervy arm doth lie,
Which, being advanc’d, declines, and then men die.

scene.stagedir: A sennet. Trumpets sound. Enter Cominius the General, and Titus Lartius; between them, Coriolanus, crown’d with an oaken garland; with Captains and Soldiers and a Roman Herald.

speech.speaker: ROM. HER.
speech.line: Know, Rome, that all alone Martius did fight
Within Corioles gates; where he hath won,
With fame, a name to Martius Caius; these
In honor follows Coriolanus.
Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!

speech.speaker: ALL.
speech.line: Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: No more of this, it does offend my heart;
Pray now, no more.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Look, sir, your mother!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: O!
You have, I know, petition’d all the gods
For my prosperity!

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: Nay, my good soldier, up;
My gentle Martius, worthy Caius, and
By deed-achieving honor newly nam’d—
What is it?—Coriolanus must I call thee?—
But O, thy wife!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: My gracious silence, hail!
Wouldst thou have laugh’d had I come coffin’d home,
That weep’st to see me triumph? Ah, my dear,
Such eyes the widows in Corioles wear,
And mothers that lack sons.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Now the gods crown thee!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: And live you yet?
O my sweet lady, pardon.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: I know not where to turn. O, welcome home;
And welcome, general, and y’ are welcome all.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: A hundred thousand welcomes! I could weep,
And I could laugh; I am light, and heavy. Welcome!
A curse begin at very root on ’s heart,
That is not glad to see thee! You are three
That Rome should dote on; yet, by the faith of men,
We have some old crab-trees here at home that will not
Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome, warriors;
We call a nettle but a nettle, and
The faults of fools but folly.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Ever right.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Menenius, ever, ever.

speech.speaker: ROM. HER.
speech.line: Give way there, and go on!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Your hand, and yours!
Ere in our own house I do shade my head,
The good patricians must be visited,
From whom I have receiv’d not only greetings,
But with them change of honors.

speech.speaker: VOL.
speech.line: I have lived
To see inherited my very wishes
And the buildings of my fancy; only
There’s one thing wanting, which I doubt not but
Our Rome will cast upon thee.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Know, good mother,
I had rather be their servant in my way
Than sway with them in theirs.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: On, to the Capitol!

scene.stagedir: Flourish. Cornets. Exeunt in state, as before. Brutus and Sicinius come forward.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights
Are spectacled to see him. Your prattling nurse
Into a rapture lets her baby cry
While she chats him; the kitchen malkin pins
Her richest lockram ’bout her reechy neck,
Clamb’ring the walls to eye him; stalls, bulks, windows
Are smother’d up, leads fill’d, and ridges hors’d
With variable complexions, all agreeing
In earnestness to see him. Seld-shown flamens
Do press among the popular throngs, and puff
To win a vulgar station; our veil’d dames
Commit the war of white and damask in
Their nicely gawded cheeks to th’ wanton spoil
Of Phoebus’ burning kisses—such a pother
As if that whatsoever god who leads him
Were slily crept into his human powers,
And gave him graceful posture.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: On the sudden,
I warrant him consul.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Then our office may,
During his power, go sleep.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: He cannot temp’rately transport his honors
From where he should begin and end, but will
Lose those he hath won.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: In that there’s comfort.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Doubt not
The commoners, for whom we stand, but they
Upon their ancient malice will forget
With the least cause these his new honors, which
That he will give them make I as little question
As he is proud to do’t.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: I heard him swear,
Were he to stand for consul, never would he
Appear i’ th’ market-place, nor on him put
The napless vesture of humility,
Nor, showing (as the manner is) his wounds
To th’ people, beg their stinking breaths.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: ’Tis right.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: It was his word. O, he would miss it rather
Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him
And the desire of the nobles.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: I wish no better
Than have him hold that purpose and to put it
In execution.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: ’Tis most like he will.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: It shall be to him then as our good wills:
A sure destruction.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: So it must fall out
To him, or our authorities, for an end.
We must suggest the people in what hatred
He still hath held them; that to ’s power he would
Have made them mules, silenc’d their pleaders, and
Dispropertied their freedoms, holding them,
In human action and capacity,
Of no more soul nor fitness for the world
Than camels in their war, who have their provand
Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows
For sinking under them.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: This, as you say, suggested
At some time when his soaring insolence
Shall teach the people—which time shall not want,
If he be put upon’t, and that’s as easy
As to set dogs on sheep—will be his fire
To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze
Shall darken him forever.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: 3. MESS.
speech.line: You are sent for to the Capitol. ’Tis thought
That Martius shall be consul.
I have seen the dumb men throng to see him, and
The blind to hear him speak. Matrons flung gloves,
Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers,
Upon him as he pass’d; the nobles bended,
As to Jove’s statue, and the commons made
A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts.
I never saw the like.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Let’s to the Capitol,
And carry with us ears and eyes for th’ time,
But hearts for the event.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Have with you.

scene.scenepersonae: (Officers, Senators, Sicinius, Brutus, Lictors, Coriolanus, Menenius, Cominius, Tribunes)
scene.stagedir: Enter two Officers to lay cushions, as it were in the Capitol.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: Come, come, they are almost here. How many stand for consulships?

speech.speaker: 2. OFF.
speech.line: Three, they say; but ’tis thought of every one Coriolanus will carry it.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: That’s a brave fellow; but he’s vengeance proud, and loves not the common people.

speech.speaker: 2. OFF.
speech.line: Faith, there hath been many great men that have flatter’d the people, who ne’er lov’d them; and there be many that they have lov’d, they know not wherefore; so that, if they love they know not why, they hate upon no better a ground. Therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate him manifests the true knowledge he has in their disposition, and out of his noble carelessness lets them plainly see’t.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: If he did not care whether he had their love or no, he wav’d indifferently ’twixt doing them neither good nor harm; but he seeks their hate with greater devotion than they can render it him, and leaves nothing undone that may fully discover him their opposite. Now, to seem to affect the malice and displeasure of the people is as bad as that which he dislikes, to flatter them for their love.

speech.speaker: 2. OFF.
speech.line: He hath deserv’d worthily of his country, and his ascent is not by such easy degrees as those who, having been supple and courteous to the people, bonneted, without any further deed to have them at all into their estimation and report. But he hath so planted his honors in their eyes and his actions in their hearts that for their tongues to be silent and not confess so much were a kind of ingrateful injury; to report otherwise were a malice that, giving itself the lie, would pluck reproof and rebuke from every ear that heard it.

speech.speaker: 1. OFF.
speech.line: No more of him, he’s a worthy man. Make way, they are coming.

scene.stagedir: A sennet. Enter the Patricians and the Tribunes of the people (Sicinius and Brutus), Lictors before them; Coriolanus, Menenius, Cominius the Consul. Sicinius and Brutus take their places by themselves. Coriolanus stands.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Having determin’d of the Volsces and
To send for Titus Lartius, it remains,
As the main point of this our after-meeting,
To gratify his noble service that
Hath thus stood for his country; therefore please you,
Most reverend and grave elders, to desire
The present consul and last general
In our well-found successes, to report
A little of that worthy work perform’d
By Martius Caius Coriolanus, whom
We met here both to thank and to remember
With honors like himself.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SEN.
speech.line: Speak, good Cominius:
Leave nothing out for length, and make us think
Rather our state’s defective for requital
Than we to stretch it out.
Masters a’ th’ people,
We do request your kindest ears, and after,
Your loving motion toward the common body
To yield what passes here.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: We are convented
Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts
Inclinable to honor and advance
The theme of our assembly.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Which the rather
We shall be blest to do, if he remember
A kinder value of the people than
He hath hereto priz’d them at.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: That’s off, that’s off;
I would you rather had been silent. Please you
To hear Cominius speak?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Most willingly;
But yet my caution was more pertinent
Than the rebuke you give it.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: He loves your people,
But tie him not to be their bedfellow.
Worthy Cominius, speak.
speech.stagedir: Coriolanus rises and offers to go away.
speech.line: Nay, keep your place.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SEN.
speech.line: Sit, Coriolanus; never shame to hear
What you have nobly done.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Your honors’ pardon;
I had rather have my wounds to heal again
Than hear say how I got them.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Sir, I hope
My words disbench’d you not?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: No, sir; yet oft,
When blows have made me stay, I fled from words.
You sooth’d not, therefore hurt not; but your people,
I love them as they weigh—

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Pray now, sit down.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: I had rather have one scratch my head i’ th’ sun
When the alarum were struck than idly sit
To hear my nothings monster’d.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Masters of the people,
Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter—
That’s thousand to one good one—when you now see
He had rather venture all his limbs for honor
Than one on ’s ears to hear it? Proceed, Cominius.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: I shall lack voice: the deeds of Coriolanus
Should not be utter’d feebly. It is held
That valor is the chiefest virtue, and
Most dignifies the haver; if it be,
The man I speak of cannot in the world
Be singly counterpois’d. At sixteen years,
When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought
Beyond the mark of others. Our then dictator,
Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight,
When with his Amazonian chin he drove
The bristled lips before him. He bestrid
An o’erpress’d Roman, and i’ th’ consul’s view
Slew three opposers. Tarquin’s self he met,
And struck him on his knee. In that day’s feats,
When he might act the woman in the scene,
He prov’d best man i’ th’ field, and for his meed
Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age
Man-ent’red thus, he waxed like a sea,
And in the brunt of seventeen battles since
He lurch’d all swords of the garland. For this last,
Before and in Corioles, let me say,
I cannot speak him home. He stopp’d the fliers,
And by his rare example made the coward
Turn terror into sport; as weeds before
A vessel under sail, so men obey’d
And fell below his stem. His sword, death’s stamp,
Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot
He was a thing of blood, whose every motion
Was tim’d with dying cries. Alone he ent’red
The mortal gate of th’ city, which he painted
With shunless destiny; aidless came off,
And with a sudden reinforcement struck
Corioles like a planet. Now all’s his,
When by and by the din of war ’gan pierce
His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit
Requick’ned what in flesh was fatigate,
And to the battle came he, where he did
Run reeking o’er the lives of men, as if
’Twere a perpetual spoil; and till we call’d
Both field and city ours, he never stood
To ease his breast with panting.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Worthy man!

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SEN.
speech.line: He cannot but with measure fit the honors
Which we devise him.

speech.speaker: COM.
speech.line: Our spoils he kick’d at,
And look’d upon things precious as they were
The common muck of the world. He covets less
Than misery itself would give, rewards
His deeds with doing them, and is content
To spend the time to end it.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: He’s right noble.
Let him be call’d for.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. SEN.
speech.line: Call Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: OFF.
speech.line: He doth appear.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: The Senate, Coriolanus, are well pleas’d
To make thee consul.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: I do owe them still
My life and services.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: It then remains
That you do speak to the people.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: I do beseech you,
Let me o’erleap that custom; for I cannot
Put on the gown, stand naked, and entreat them
For my wounds’ sake to give their suffrage. Please you
That I may pass this doing.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Sir, the people
Must have their voices; neither will they bate
One jot of ceremony.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Put them not to’t.
Pray you go fit you to the custom, and
Take to you, as your predecessors have,
Your honor with your form.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: It is a part
That I shall blush in acting, and might well
Be taken from the people.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Mark you that.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: To brag unto them, “Thus I did, and thus!”
Show them th’ unaching scars which I should hide,
As if I had receiv’d them for the hire
Of their breath only!

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: Do not stand upon’t.
We recommend to you, tribunes of the people,
Our purpose to them, and to our noble consul
Wish we all joy and honor.

speech.speaker: SENATORS.
speech.line: To Coriolanus come all joy and honor!

scene.stagedir: Flourish cornets. Then exeunt. Manent Sicinius and Brutus.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: You see how he intends to use the people.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: May they perceive ’s intent! He will require them
As if he did contemn what he requested
Should be in them to give.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Come, we’ll inform them
Of our proceedings here on th’ market-place;
I know they do attend us.

scene.scenepersonae: (Roman Citizens, Coriolanus, Menenius, Brutus, Sicinius, Plebeians)
scene.stagedir: Enter seven or eight Roman Citizens.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Once if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: We may, sir, if we will.

speech.speaker: 3. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a power that we have no power to do; for if he show us his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are to put our tongues into those wounds and speak for them; so, if he tell us his noble deeds, we must also tell him our noble acceptance of them. Ingratitude is monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful were to make a monster of the multitude; of the which we being members, should bring ourselves to be monstrous members.

speech.speaker: 1. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: And to make us no better thought of, a little help will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.

speech.speaker: 3. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: We have been call’d so of many, not that our heads are some brown, some black, some abram, some bald, but that our wits are so diversely color’d; and truly I think if all our wits were to issue out of one skull, they would fly east, west, north, south, and their consent of one direct way should be at once to all the points a’ th’ compass.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would fly?

speech.speaker: 3. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man’s will; ’tis strongly wadg’d up in a block-head; but if it were at liberty, ’twould sure southward.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Why that way?

speech.speaker: 3. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return for conscience’ sake to help to get thee a wife.

speech.speaker: 2. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: You are never without your tricks; you may, you may.

speech.speaker: 3. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Are you all resolv’d to give your voices? But that’s no matter, the greater part carries it, I say. If he would incline to the people, there was never a worthier man.
speech.stagedir: Enter Coriolanus in a gown of humility, with Menenius.
speech.line: Here he comes, and in the gown of humility, mark his behavior. We are not to stay all together, but to come by him where he stands, by ones, by twos, and by threes. He’s to make his requests by particulars, wherein every one of us has a single honor, in giving him our own voices with our own tongues; therefore follow me, and I’ll direct you how you shall go by him.

speech.speaker: ALL. ROM. CIT.
speech.line: Content, content.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: O sir, you are not right. Have you not known
The worthiest men have done’t?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: What must I say?
“I pray, sir”—Plague upon’t! I cannot bring
My tongue to such a pace. “Look, sir, my wounds!
I got them in my country’s service, when
Some certain of your brethren roar’d, and ran
From th’ noise of our own drums.”

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: O me, the gods!
You must not speak of that. You must desire them
To think upon you.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Think upon me? Hang ’em,
I would they would forget me, like the virtues
Which our divines lose by ’em.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: You’ll mar all.
I’ll leave you. Pray you speak to ’em, I pray you,
In wholesome manner.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Bid them wash their faces,
And keep their teeth clean. So, here comes a brace.—
You know the cause, sir, of my standing here.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: We do, sir, tell us what hath brought you to’t.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Mine own desert.

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: Your own desert!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Ay, not mine own desire.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: How, not your own desire?

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: No, sir, ’twas never my desire yet to trouble the poor with begging.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: You must think, if we give you any thing, we hope to gain by you.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Well then, I pray, your price a’ th’ consulship?

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: The price is, to ask it kindly.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Kindly, sir, I pray let me ha’t. I have wounds to show you, which shall be yours in private. Your good voice, sir, what say you?

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: You shall ha’t, worthy sir.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: A match, sir. There’s in all two worthy voices begg’d. I have your alms, adieu.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: But this is something odd.

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: And ’twere to give again—but ’tis no matter.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your voices that I may be consul, I have here the customary gown.

speech.speaker: 4. CIT.
speech.line: You have deserv’d nobly of your country, and you have not deserv’d nobly.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Your enigma?

speech.speaker: 4. CIT.
speech.line: You have been a scourge to her enemies, you have been a rod to her friends; you have not indeed lov’d the common people.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: You should account me the more virtuous that I have not been common in my love. I will, sir, flatter my sworn brother, the people, to earn a dearer estimation of them; ’tis a condition they account gentle. And since the wisdom of their choice is rather to have my hat than my heart, I will practice the insinuating nod and be off to them most counterfeitly; that is, sir, I will counterfeit the bewitchment of some popular man, and give it bountiful to the desirers. Therefore beseech you I may be consul.

speech.speaker: 5. CIT.
speech.line: We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give you our voices heartily.

speech.speaker: 4. CIT.
speech.line: You have receiv’d many wounds for your country.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no farther.

speech.speaker: BOTH 4. CIT. AND 5. CIT.
speech.line: The gods give you joy, sir, heartily!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Most sweet voices!
Better it is to die, better to starve,
Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.
Why in this woolvish toge should I stand here
To beg of Hob and Dick, that does appear,
Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to’t.
What custom wills, in all things should we do’t,
The dust on antique time would lie unswept,
And mountainous error be too highly heap’d
For truth to o’erpeer. Rather than fool it so,
Let the high office and the honor go
To one that would do thus. I am half through:
The one part suffered, the other will I do.
Here come more voices.—
Your voices? For your voices I have fought;
Watch’d for your voices; for your voices bear
Of wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice six
I have seen, and heard of; for your voices have
Done many things, some less, some more. Your voices?
Indeed I would be consul.

speech.speaker: 6. CIT.
speech.line: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest man’s voice.

speech.speaker: 7. CIT.
speech.line: Therefore let him be consul. The gods give him joy, and make him good friend to the people!

speech.speaker: ALL CITIZENS.
speech.line: Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul!

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Worthy voices!

scene.stagedir: Enter Menenius with Brutus and Sicinius.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: You have stood your limitation, and the tribunes
Endue you with the people’s voice. Remains
That, in th’ official marks invested, you
Anon do meet the Senate.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Is this done?

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: The custom of request you have discharg’d.
The people do admit you and are summon’d
To meet anon, upon your approbation.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: Where? At the Senate-house?

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: There, Coriolanus.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: May I change these garments?

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: You may, sir.

speech.speaker: COR.
speech.line: That I’ll straight do; and, knowing myself again,
Repair to th’ Senate-house.

speech.speaker: MEN.
speech.line: I’ll keep you company. Will you along?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: We stay here for the people.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Fare you well.
He has it now; and by his looks, methinks,
’Tis warm at ’s heart.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: With a proud heart he wore his humble weeds.
Will you dismiss the people?

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: How now, my masters, have you chose this man?

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: He has our voices, sir.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: Amen, sir. To my poor unworthy notice,
He mock’d us when he begg’d our voices.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: Certainly,
He flouted us downright.

speech.speaker: 1. CIT.
speech.line: No, ’tis his kind of speech, he did not mock us.

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
speech.line: Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says
He us’d us scornfully. He should have show’d us
His marks of merit, wounds receiv’d for ’s country.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Why, so he did, I am sure.

speech.speaker: ALL CITIZENS.
speech.line: No, no; no man saw ’em.

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: He said he had wounds, which he could show in private;
And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn,
“I would be consul,” says he; “aged custom,
But by your voices, will not so permit me;
Your voices therefore.” When we granted that,
Here was “I thank you for your voices, thank you,
Your most sweet voices. Now you have left your voices,
I have no further with you.” Was not this mockery?

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Why either were you ignorant to see’t,
Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness
To yield your voices?

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Could you not have told him
As you were lesson’d: when he had no power,
But was a petty servant to the state,
He was your enemy, ever spake against
Your liberties and the charters that you bear
I’ th’ body of the weal; and now, arriving
A place of potency and sway o’ th’ state,
If he should still malignantly remain
Fast foe to th’ plebeii, your voices might
Be curses to yourselves? You should have said
That as his worthy deeds did claim no less
Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature
Would think upon you for your voices, and
Translate his malice towards you into love,
Standing your friendly lord.

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Thus to have said,
As you were fore-advis’d, had touch’d his spirit
And tried his inclination; from him pluck’d
Either his gracious promise, which you might,
As cause had call’d you up, have held him to;
Or else it would have gall’d his surly nature,
Which easily endures not article
Tying him to aught; so putting him to rage,
You should have ta’en th’ advantage of his choler,
And pass’d him unelected.

speech.speaker: BRU.
speech.line: Did you perceive
He did solicit you in free contempt
When he did need your loves; and do you think
That his contempt shall not be bruising to you
When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies
No heart among you? Or had you tongues to cry
Against the rectorship of judgement?

speech.speaker: SIC.
speech.line: Have you
Ere now denied the asker; and now again,
Of him that did not ask but mock, bestow
Your su’d-for tongues?

speech.speaker: 3. CIT.
speech.line: He’s not confirm’d, we may deny him yet.

speech.speaker: 2. CIT.
